arm_group.description: ParentCorps is a school-based, family-focused universal intervention designed to attenuate the multiple risks associated with urban poverty, on children's health and development

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study was to determine whether ParentCorps promotes academic achievement
      and prevents mental health problems in children living in disadvantaged urban communities

clinical_study.brief_title: ParentCorps: Promoting Healthy Development in Children From Low Income Communities
clinical_study.condition: Behavior Problems of Childhood and Adolescence

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Enrollment in Pre-K

          -  At least one English-Speaking caregiver

        Exclusion Criteria:

intervention.description: ParentCorps is a culturally-informed, universal intervention (for all children enrolled in Pre-K within an elementary school) designed to promote positive behavioral supports for children at home and in the classroom. ParentCorps includes two complementary components: 1) parent and child group intervention (13 2-hour sessions after school) for Pre-K students and their families; 2) professional development and individual consultation for early childhood teachers.

facility.name: New York University School of Medicine, The Child Study Center

clinical_study.official_title: Preventing Conduct Problems in Poor Urban Preschoolers

overall_official.affiliation: New York University School of Medicine

primary_outcome.description: Academic achievement test scores assessed via the Kaufman Test of Educational Achievement (KTEA)
primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Academic achievement through Year 4
primary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed twice per year in Years 1 and 2, and then annually through Year 4

primary_outcome.description: Masked observations of child behavior at school
primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Child behavior at school through Year 4
primary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed twice per year in Years 1 and 2, and then annually through Year 6

reference.citation: Brotman LM, Calzada E, Huang KY, Kingston S, Dawson-McClure S, Kamboukos D, Rosenfelt A, Schwab A, Petkova E. Promoting effective parenting practices and preventing child behavior problems in school among ethnically diverse families from underserved, urban communities. Child Dev. 2011 Jan-Feb;82(1):258-76. doi: 10.1111/j.1467-8624.2010.01554.x.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

results_reference.citation: Brotman LM, Dawson-McClure S, Huang KY, Theise R, Kamboukos D, Wang J, Petkova E, Ogedegbe G. Early childhood family intervention and long-term obesity prevention among high-risk minority youth. Pediatrics. 2012 Mar;129(3):e621-8. doi: 10.1542/peds.2011-1568. Epub 2012 Feb 6.

secondary_outcome.description: Teacher and parent ratings of academic performance
secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline Academic performance through Year 4
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed twice per year in Years 1 and 2, and then annually through Year 6

secondary_outcome.description: Teacher and parent ratings of behavior
secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline Behavior through Year 4
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed twice per year in Years 1 and 2, and then annually through Year 6

secondary_outcome.description: Teacher rating of parent engagement in school
secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline Parent engagement in school through Year 4
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed twice per year in Years 1 and 2, and then annually through Year 6

secondary_outcome.description: Parent report of positive behavior support
secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline Positive behavior support through Year 4
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed twice per year in Years 1 and 2

secondary_outcome.description: Masked observations of classroom climate and positive behavior support
secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline Classroom climate and positive behavior support through Year 4
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed twice per year in Years 1 and 2, and then annually through Year 4

clinical_study.source: New York University School of Medicine

lead_sponsor.agency: New York University School of Medicine

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Prevention
